techniques.name: Drive-by Compromise
techniques.description: Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website that exploits the browser or a plugin to execute code.

techniques.name: Phishing
techniques.description: Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access, typically via malicious attachments or links in email.

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse existing account credentials to gain initial access or persist within an environment.

techniques.name: User Execution: Malicious File
techniques.description: An adversary relies on a user opening a malicious file to execute code on the local system.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution, leveraging its deep OS integration.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse cmd.exe to execute commands, scripts, or binaries on Windows systems.

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse VBScript or VBA macros for execution, often delivered via Office documents.

techniques.name: Scheduled Task/Job
techniques.description: Adversaries may create scheduled tasks or jobs to execute malicious code at system startup or on a recurring schedule.

techniques.name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
techniques.description: Adversaries may add programs to the Run registry keys or Startup folder so they execute each time a user logs on.

techniques.name: Create or Modify System Process
techniques.description: Adversaries may create or modify Windows services to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence.

techniques.name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Shortcut Modification
techniques.description: Adversaries may modify shortcut files to execute their payload when the user clicks the shortcut.

techniques.name: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism
techniques.description: Adversaries may circumvent UAC or other elevation control mechanisms to gain higher privileges on a system.

techniques.name: Process Injection: Dynamic-link Library Injection
techniques.description: Adversaries may inject DLLs into processes to evade defenses and elevate privileges by executing in the context of another process.

techniques.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
techniques.description: Adversaries may obfuscate payloads through encoding, encryption, or steganography to hinder detection.

techniques.name: Impair Defenses
techniques.description: Adversaries may disable or tamper with security tools, firewall rules, or logging to evade detection.

techniques.name: Indicator Removal
techniques.description: Adversaries may delete or modify logs, files, or artifacts to remove evidence of their activity.

techniques.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
techniques.description: Adversaries may deobfuscate or decode encoded files or information used during an intrusion.

techniques.name: System Binary Proxy Execution
techniques.description: Adversaries may use trusted system binaries to proxy execution of malicious content to bypass application controls.

techniques.name: Credentials from Password Stores
techniques.description: Adversaries may search password stores such as browser credential databases to obtain user credentials.

techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.description: Adversaries may dump credentials from the operating system using tools like Mimikatz to obtain account passwords or hashes.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.description: Adversaries may use brute force password guessing or credential stuffing to gain access to accounts.

techniques.name: Input Capture: Keylogging
techniques.description: Adversaries may log keystrokes to intercept credentials and other sensitive information as users type.

techniques.name: Unsecured Credentials
techniques.description: Adversaries may search file systems or registries for insecurely stored credentials.

techniques.name: System Information Discovery
techniques.description: An adversary may gather detailed system information including OS version, hardware, and patches to aid targeting.

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories to locate data of interest before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Process Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may enumerate running processes to understand software and security tools on the system.

techniques.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may look for network configuration details such as IP addresses, DNS, and routing to inform further actions.

techniques.name: Remote Services
techniques.description: Adversaries may use valid accounts to log into remote services such as RDP or SMB to move laterally within a network.

techniques.name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may use RDP to remotely log into systems for lateral movement and interactive access.

techniques.name: Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.description: Adversaries may use SMB shares like C$ and ADMIN$ to move laterally and transfer files between systems.

techniques.name: Data from Local System
techniques.description: Adversaries may search local system sources such as file systems and databases for sensitive data before exfiltration.

techniques.name: Archive Collected Data
techniques.description: An adversary may compress or encrypt collected data before exfiltration to reduce the size and avoid detection.

techniques.name: Clipboard Data
techniques.description: Adversaries may collect data stored in the clipboard from users copying information within or between applications.

techniques.name: Application Layer Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may communicate using common application layer protocols such as HTTP, HTTPS, or DNS to blend with normal traffic.

techniques.name: Encrypted Channel
techniques.description: Adversaries may encrypt C2 communications using symmetric or asymmetric encryption to avoid detection.

techniques.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
techniques.description: Adversaries may transfer tools or files from an external system into a compromised environment.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
techniques.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data over the existing command and control channel rather than creating a separate connection.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Web Service
techniques.description: Adversaries may use legitimate web services such as cloud storage to exfiltrate data from a network.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data using a protocol other than the existing C2 channel, such as DNS or FTP.

techniques.name: Data Encrypted for Impact
techniques.description: Adversaries may encrypt data on target systems to interrupt availability, typically as part of a ransomware attack.

techniques.name: Service Stop
techniques.description: Adversaries may stop or disable services to render resources unavailable, often targeting security or backup services.

techniques.name: Inhibit System Recovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may delete or disable system recovery features such as shadow copies to prevent restoration after encryption.
